I think most physicalists are fine with fields and not tied to particles in particular, although the fact that as went from particles to fields shows how Hemple's Dilemma is a big problem.

The problem comes in when you want to deny that mathematical truths and abstracta exist but also are saying everything is made of fields. You're sort of pointing at your map and saying "this is the territory, not the map!" And then someone points out that you're pointing at a map, and you say "no, the map isn't even real, we just made that up, but look I used the map to get from point A to B, which proves that the territory and the map are the same thing, it's just that the map part of it is fake."

But yes, the transcendental shaping of our cognition, how it influences our models, and how the existence of non-existence of noumena independent of mind could ever make a difference to anyone (how they could ever not be identical from all perspectives) is certainly an underrated problem. But I also feel like that would be true even if physicalism of some kind was true, right?

The part that seems salient is how evolution shapes perception and how this inevitably shapes all models and intuitions, giving us huge blinders. But this more fodder for skepticism than another ontology depending on how you look at it, no?

I suppose if you have to put all your faith in logic though, objective logic ontologies might seem more inviting.

This is what the wave equation looks like if you plot it. You can see that it encloses what appears to be a kind of ball shape that's moving along through space. That ball shape is the probability density, which is a 3D volume, and the idea is that the actual particle is somewhere within that ball shape. Kind of like a marble inside a basketball. But in this case while the size of the basketball is well defined the size of the marble is not. It is known to be extremely small compared to the basketball but it's so small that even if it does have some kind of volume it's negligible and mathematically it's considered a 1D point. This is for a photon, some other particles can be measurably bigger as far as I know. There's some answers here too on what is the size of a photon

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>15034981
Normally CO concentration is too low to be a concern, it's the hardest to remove too. CO is problematic if you're burning something indoor.
VOC comes mainly from the room itself unless you live in an industrial zone, near gas station. Activated charcoal woks (it has some limit capacity) and doesn't remove all without a lot of circulation. The best way to remove VOC is avoid it in first place, and ventilate.
You should worry more about dust (and NO2) from the outside than VOC, CO2 or CO.
CO2, do you want some "CO2 free" room? with normal dust-free ventilation you should be able to have less than 800-1000ppm of CO2, good enough for indoors.

Absorbing completely all the CO2 inside the room would need at least 50kg of NaOH per year, well into the category of "suspicious". And would be useless.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15035758
Presumably the families know what kind of children they have, the perspective would be an observer who only knows what the question teller tells them. Consider it this way:
You're told that a population exists of families with between 1 and infinity children, how likely is it that a family in that population has 1 girl? Probably approaching 100%
Now you are told that if you picked a family with other than 2 children, they will be discarded and you pick another. Now what's the probability that the family you finally pick that qualifies has 1 girl? 50%
Now you're told that if you pick a family with 2 boys, it will be discarded and you have to pick again. The chance of exactly 1 girl is now 2/3.

My understanding is that the question is doing this narrowing but more concisely, and it's eliminating the non-matching parts of the population of families before you pick anything but you still end up with a possible population matching the same odds.

Sorry wrong screen grab. proof below

>write a comprehensive mathematical proof to find a strong general solution the Navier Stokes smoothness equation.

The equation is as follows:

$$ rac{\partial u}{\partial t} + u\cdot abla u = - rac{1}{ ho} abla p + u abla^2 u$$

where $u$ is the velocity field, $t$ is the time, $ ho$ is the density, $p$ is the pressure, and $ u$ is the viscosity.

To prove a strong general solution to the Navier-Stokes equation, we will first assume that the solution exists and is continuous. We will then use the method of characteristics to show that the solution is unique and can be determined by the initial conditions.

We begin by rewriting the equation in terms of characteristics, which are the paths along which the solution propagates. We denote the characteristic line by $x(s)$ and the solution by $u(x,t)$:

$$ rac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{d}s} + u\cdot abla_x u = - rac{1}{ ho} abla_x p + u abla_x^2 u$$

where $s$ is the arc length along the characteristic, $ abla_x$ is the gradient with respect to $x$, and $ abla_x^2$ is the Laplacian with respect to $x$.

Next, we will use the method of characteristics to show that the solution is unique and can be determined by the initial conditions. We denote the initial conditions by $u_0(x)$. We assume that the solution exists and is continuous and use the method of characteristics to solve the equation.

Integrating the equation with respect to $s$ yields:

$$u(x,t) = u_0(x(s_0)) + \int_{s_0}^s \left(- rac{1}{ ho} abla_x p + u abla_x^2 u ight) \mathrm{d}s$$

where $s_0$ is the initial value of the arc length along the characteristic.

We can now use the initial conditions to determine the solution. Since the solution is continuous, we can integrate the equation from $s_0$ to $s$ to obtain:

$$u(x,t) = u_0(x(s_0)) + \int_{s_0}^s \left(- rac{1}{ ho} abla_x p + u abla_x^2 u ight) \mathrm{d}s = u_0(x)$$

We use the GRE instead of IQ tests because you can get better predictions if you include some learned knowledge, but keep it pretty general.

last_replies.com:
>>15035223
Anon, the answer considers a different (from the usual) semantics that is still sound for the proposed Hilbert system.
Now if the axiom system was complete w.r.t. the usual classical semantics, then any classical tautology must be a theorem of that proof system. But as we proved the system sound w.r.t. the new semantics, any theorem must be a tautology of the new semantics (what they called a 0-tautology).
Summing up, any classical tautology must be a 0-tautology, but the answer pointed out one particular formula for which this fails.

It's worth mentioning that this entire "coming up with a different sound semantics" was mostly to help us find our counterexample (in the form of that classical tautology). If someone were to tell you to consider that formula from the start, you could simply show that it is a classical tautology but not entailed by the proof system (this part would require induction as our proof system is inductively defined)

sub: Winter Course in Geometric Measure Theory
com:
Hello. There is an organized reading course in Geometric Measure Theory being held from 10 Dec to 21 Jan. This will cover sections 2.1-2.6/7 of the textbook "Geometric Measure Theory" by Herbert Federer. Once this session is completed, a new schedule will be determined to continue reading deeper into the text. Problem sets and reading assignments will be posted at the beginning of each week, to be discussed the following Saturday during a group meeting.

The prerequisites for this reading course are point-set topology, linear algebra, undergraduate real analysis, and abstract algebra (standard undergraduate maths education). The textbook is self-contained with respect to measure theory, differential geometry, and algebraic topology. Therefore, you do not need to know those three subjects to participate. You are welcome to join.

A teaspoon equals 5 ml and an oz equals 29,57 ml.
Every unit of the recipe requires 5 ml of x + 5 ml of y + 10 ml of z = 20 ml in total

I was reading about early attempts at creating high frequency electric currents before vacuum tubes were really a thing, and I came up with this design. It seems way too simple, and there's no way that no one would have thought of it back then, so there has to be some reason why it wouldn't work as expected.

The basic idea is that you take a faraday disk (a thin copper disk with wires attached to the center and outer edge), and use an electromagnet to create a magnetic field in its axial direction. When a capacitor is connected to the electromagnet, the current inside of it oscillates, which causes the magnetic field it produces to rapidly switch direction. Spinning the disk in this alternating magnetic field would produce an alternating current at the resonant frequency of the LC oscillator. This current can be used to continuously feed the LC oscillator to keep the field alternating. As long as you keep feeding energy into the system by spinning the disk, shouldn't it keep oscillating?

com:
The Function of Moles: A Remnant of a Defunct Hair-Shedding Mechanism Left Over from Human Ancestors; Implications for Alopecia and Neval Cell Mutagenicity

Moles, being that they are arguably unsightly and potentially mutagenic, have baffled biologists but have sparked little serious research into the historical evolutionary function of the virtually ubiquitous human feature.

I would put forth the notion that it is the very property of moles that made them useful to human ancestors that makes their transformation into tumor cells more likely than that of the average skin cell. That is to say that the principal property that sets them apart from ordinary skin cells is a latent, undiscovered tendency to make copies of proteins.

While it is known that the formation of hair follicles is driven largely by Follicle-Stimulating Hormone and that an absence of this hormone may lead to alopecia resulting from the halting of cellular function of those follicles, what has not been properly studied are the proteins secreted by existing follicles and how they impact the behavior of neighboring follicles.

The investigation of these proteins and their interplay with mole (neval) cells may not only answer a longstanding question as to the purpose of moles, but could bring us a great deal closer to curing alopecia (or inducing it purposefully as an alternative to painful hair removal.)

A fairly rudimentary observation of moles is that they often feature unusually long, coarse hairs protruding from within. It stands to reason that thicker, faster-growing hairs come from follicles that are more active and thus can be assumed to express greater quantities of proteins.

last_replies.name: YWPTS
last_replies.com:
I propose that the collocation of these coarse hairs with moles is not coincidental. Early human ancestors were covered nearly entirely with hair. Most fur-covered animals have a shedding process to aid in regulating body temperature seasonally. In these animals, a variety of mechanisms may be at work in signalling warmer weather and the need for shedding a large portion of a coat.

In human ancestors, at least, I feel confident that moles took a protein secreted by the one or two "mole hairs" and acted as a cellular machine to duplicate those proteins in differing amounts depending upon temperature. If the temperature of the mole increased to, say, around 95°F, it kicked into overdrive to make copies of a messenger RNA originating in the follicle of the mole hair.

These RNAs, multiplied millions of times by neval cells, would diffuse into the local dermis and their abundance would signal to other hair follicles to chemically separate from growing hairs, causing shedding. This process may, indeed, be the key to understanding and treating alopecia.

The high concentration of the mRNA molecules associated with high mole temperatures and the shedding process may cause shedding (without permanently preventing future hair growth) in part thanks to the bio-similarity of those RNAs to those comprising the interior of the follicles affected. Hair growth rates are regulated ultimately, I propose, by the secretion of these RNAs, which act to cause frequent but brief pauses in growth under normal conditions. Too great of a quantity of these proteins on the interior of a follicle results in the detachment of the hair from the follicle i.e. shedding.

last_replies.name: YWPTS
last_replies.com:
For human ancestors and perhaps some modern day primate species, warm weather is enough to result in measurable shedding. Modern humans have so little body hair by comparison that shedding signals, while likely still being sent, do not cause visible shedding. This has resulted in a failure by biologists to make the connection between mole organelles and shedding.

If confirmed, this hypothesis may lead to a safe mRNA-based reversible hair removal/growth induction method.

If moles are, indeed, capable of making large numbers of copies of mRNA, it would go a long way toward explaining the mutagenicity of moles. While basal cells have been provably linked to UV-related carcinomas, the assumption that mole (neval) cells become cancerous due to UV exposure is likely false. Conversely, chemicals that come into contact with moles are more likely the cause of most cancers of mole cells. The application of sunblock containing carcinogenic substances such as titanium dioxide and exposure of moles to other chemicals is a far more likely cause of mutations to neval cells given their tendency to attempt dupliction of any chemical that comes in contact with the cells. Unlike most cells, which attempt to restrict entry by harmful chemicals in order to maintain integrity, neval cells permit entry of all chemicals in order to attempt replication. If the chemical cannot be duplicated, the neval cell will self-duplicate (leading to irregular shape but not necessarily cancer.) If the chemical in question interferes in the self-duplication process, a cancer can result.

This considered, we once again can see how taking the time to solve a mystery of no obvious consequence can bear fruit in the form of unexpected research overruns.

com: How do I learn maths? I only know basic arithmetic. I havent been in school for a long time.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15034614
I'd recommend starting with some basic high school level algebra and then slowly working through some easier discrete math topics (counting problems, rearrangements, etc.)

Once you've gotten a decent grasp of some of the counting and combinatorics as well as some of the basic language of proofs you'll be in great shape to work towards more advanced algebra and trigonometry.

Ultimately everything in the beginning is working towards calculus (which is what opens the door to the more interesting and meaningful disciplines). If you can build a decent algebra, combinatorics, proofs and trig background, then calculus will be a really rewarding study and should provide you the basics to approach almost any topic you could desire.
